elements.content: A new type of 3D “strongly” self-catenated metal–organic framework (SDU-9) has been constructed from [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel secondary building units and a tripodal carboxylate linker. SDU-9 ([Cu6(H2O)6 L 4]·24H2O, where [H3 L = 4,4′,4″-(hydroxysilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-4-carboxylic acid), represents a rare example of a highly symmetrical coordination network and extremely tight self-catenation. To the best of our knowledge, SDU-9 has the highest topological density among all known 3,4-coordinated nets.
elements.clean_text: A new type of 3D "strongly" self-catenated metal-organic framework (SDU-9) has been constructed from [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel secondary building units and a tripodal carboxylate linker. SDU-9 ([Cu6(H2O)6 L 4]⋅24H2O, where [H3 L = 4,4',4"-(hydroxysilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-4-carboxylic acid), represents a rare example of a highly symmetrical coordination network and extremely tight self-catenation. To the best of our knowledge, SDU-9 has the highest topological density among all known 3,4-coordinated nets.

elements.content: A new type of 3D “strongly” self-catenated metal−organic framework (SDU-9) has been constructed from [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel secondary building units and a tripodal carboxylate linker. Unlike the previously reported self-interpenetrated net, SDU-9 represents a rare example of a highly symmetrical coordination network and extremely tight self-catenation. To the best of our knowledge, SDU-9 has the highest topological density among all known 3,4-coordinated nets.
elements.clean_text: A new type of 3D "strongly" self-catenated metal-organic framework (SDU-9) has been constructed from [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel secondary building units and a tripodal carboxylate linker. Unlike the previously reported self-interpenetrated net, SDU-9 represents a rare example of a highly symmetrical coordination network and extremely tight self-catenation. To the best of our knowledge, SDU-9 has the highest topological density among all known 3,4-coordinated nets.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have caused an upsurge of interest not only for their potential applications in gas adsorption, catalysis, ion exchange, biomedical applications, etc., but also for their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. The network topological approach proposed by Wells is an important and essential aspect of the analysis, comparison, and design of MOFs by reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-connection reference nets. In the past decade, many structural types and entanglement topological features unprecedented in the world of inorganic compounds and minerals have been unmasked in the MOF field. Recently, Yang and co-workers described a silver coordination polymer with a record 54 interpenetrating networks, which provide a new template for future highly interpenetrated or self-catenated structures.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have caused an upsurge of interest not only for their potential applications in gas adsorption, catalysis, ion exchange, biomedical applications, etc., but also for their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. The network topological approach proposed by Wells is an important and essential aspect of the analysis, comparison, and design of MOFs by reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-connection reference nets. In the past decade, many structural types and entanglement topological features unprecedented in the world of inorganic compounds and minerals have been unmasked in the MOF field. Recently, Yang and co-workers described a silver coordination polymer with a record 54 interpenetrating networks, which provide a new template for future highly interpenetrated or self-catenated structures.

elements.content: Among the different types of entanglements, such as interpenetration, polycatenation, polythreading, and self-catenation (other equivalent terms are self-penetration or polyknotting), interpenetrating networks are the most abundant and most comprehensively studied objects, as shown in the extensive reviews. However, the study of self-catenated networks considered as extended periodic equivalents of molecular knots remains largely unexplored. These structures are single networks with regions in which chains from the same net pass through smallest topological circuits in a fashion similar to that of interpenetrating systems. Recently, uninodal (with one kind of node) self-catenated coordination networks were reviewed by Ke et al. According to the list given by Batten in a web site (http://www.chem.monash.edu.au/staff/sbatten/interpen/examples7.html), a few examples of self-catenated networks with nodes of different connectivity such as 4,4-, 3,5-, 3,6-, and 3,12-connections have been observed; however, reports on a self-catenated 3,4-coordinated network are quite rare. Mu et al. reported an unusual 3,4-coordinated self-catenated network that can be viewed as the cross-linking of a 2D + 2D → 3D inclined polycatenation. Similarly, most of the self-catenated networks can be represented as interweaved arrays of 2D or 3D individual equivalent components after breaking some edges, which we call the “weakly” self-catenated nets, in order to discriminate the net reported here. Generally, most reported self-catenated nets are constructed from flexible organic ligands; reports on rigid carboxylate ligands are somewhat rare. To construct such self-catenated nets, the conformation and linking mode of the organic ligand seem very important.
elements.clean_text: Among the different types of entanglements, such as interpenetration, polycatenation, polythreading, and self-catenation (other equivalent terms are self-penetration or polyknotting), interpenetrating networks are the most abundant and most comprehensively studied objects, as shown in the extensive reviews. However, the study of self-catenated networks considered as extended periodic equivalents of molecular knots remains largely unexplored. These structures are single networks with regions in which chains from the same net pass through smallest topological circuits in a fashion similar to that of interpenetrating systems. Recently, uninodal (with one kind of node) self-catenated coordination networks were reviewed by Ke et al. According to the list given by Batten in a web site (http://www.chem.monash.edu.au/staff/sbatten/interpen/examples7.html), a few examples of self-catenated networks with nodes of different connectivity such as 4,4-, 3,5-, 3,6-, and 3,12-connections have been observed; however, reports on a self-catenated 3,4-coordinated network are quite rare. Mu et al. reported an unusual 3,4-coordinated self-catenated network that can be viewed as the cross-linking of a 2D + 2D → 3D inclined polycatenation. Similarly, most of the self-catenated networks can be represented as interweaved arrays of 2D or 3D individual equivalent components after breaking some edges, which we call the "weakly" self-catenated nets, in order to discriminate the net reported here. Generally, most reported self-catenated nets are constructed from flexible organic ligands; reports on rigid carboxylate ligands are somewhat rare. To construct such self-catenated nets, the conformation and linking mode of the organic ligand seem very important.

elements.content: Recently, we reported a series of porous 3,24-coordinated rht-type MOFs based on C 3v -symmetry silicon-based hexatopic carboxylate linkers. According to the TOPOS TTD collection, in total there are 20 examples of rht-type coordination networks, the first of which were synthesized in 2008. Developing our previous results, in this work, we have synthesized a new tripodal organic ligand, 4,4′,4″-(hydroxysilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-4-carboxylic acid) (H3 L). Surprisingly, the solvothermal assembly of H3 L and copper paddlewheel secondary building units (SBUs) resulted in the formation of a novel “strongly” self-catenated MOF ([Cu6(H2O)6 L 4]·24H2O, which is quite different from other MOFs based on tripodal carboxylate ligands and paddlewheel SBUs.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we reported a series of porous 3,24-coordinated rht-type MOFs based on C 3v -symmetry silicon-based hexatopic carboxylate linkers. According to the TOPOS TTD collection, in total there are 20 examples of rht-type coordination networks, the first of which were synthesized in 2008. Developing our previous results, in this work, we have synthesized a new tripodal organic ligand, 4,4',4"-(hydroxysilanetriyl)tris(triphenyl-4-carboxylic acid) (H3 L). Surprisingly, the solvothermal assembly of H3 L and copper paddlewheel secondary building units (SBUs) resulted in the formation of a novel "strongly" self-catenated MOF ([Cu6(H2O)6 L 4]⋅24H2O, which is quite different from other MOFs based on tripodal carboxylate ligands and paddlewheel SBUs.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2·6H2O with H3 L (Figure a) in N,N-dimethylformamide/ethanol/water [1:1:1 (v/v/v), 10 mL] at 75 °C for 2000 min yields cubic green crystals of SDU-9. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that SDU-9 crystallizes in the chiral cubic space group F432. Two copper ions are bridged by four carboxylates to form the well-known paddlewheel [Cu2(COO)4] SBU (Figure b). Each SBU connects four organic ligands, and each ligand binds three SBUs to form a 3D 3,4-coordinated self-catenated MOF containing right-handed helices along the [1,0,1] direction (Figure d). The connection type between the helices is different (Figure c): one is connected through the [Cu2(COO)4] SBU, and the other is linked through the silicon atom.
elements.clean_text: The solvothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2⋅6H2O with H3 L (Figure a) in N,N-dimethylformamide/ethanol/water [1:1:1 (v/v/v), 10 mL] at 75 °C for 2000 min yields cubic green crystals of SDU-9. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that SDU-9 crystallizes in the chiral cubic space group F432. Two copper ions are bridged by four carboxylates to form the well-known paddlewheel [Cu2(COO)4] SBU (Figure b). Each SBU connects four organic ligands, and each ligand binds three SBUs to form a 3D 3,4-coordinated self-catenated MOF containing right-handed helices along the [1,0,1] direction (Figure d). The connection type between the helices is different (Figure c): one is connected through the [Cu2(COO)4] SBU, and the other is linked through the silicon atom.

elements.content: (a) Organic ligand used in this work. (b) Coordination environment of CuII ions in SDU-9 with thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (c) Connection type between the helical chains (viewed along the [0,1,–1] direction). (d) Perspective view of the helical chain along the [1,0,1] direction in SDU-9 (top) and the 1D channel (bottom). (e) 3D packing of SDU-9 along [1,0,0] direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Organic ligand used in this work. (b) Coordination environment of CuII ions in SDU-9 with thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (c) Connection type between the helical chains (viewed along the [0,1,-1] direction). (d) Perspective view of the helical chain along the [1,0,1] direction in SDU-9 (top) and the 1D channel (bottom). (e) 3D packing of SDU-9 along [1,0,0] direction.

elements.content: To perform topological analysis of the 3D architecture, we have used the TOPOS program package. Topologically, by regarding each Cu2-SBU as a 4-coordinated node (Figure ) and each L as a 3-coordinated node (Figure ), the overall 3D net can be rationalized as a binodal 3,4-coordinated edge-transitive (with one kind of edge) underlying net (i.e., the net of centroids of structural groups) with the point symbol of (123)4(126)3 (Figure ). It is striking that this net has collisions; i.e., some of its vertices have coordinates that are the average of the coordinates of their neighbors. This feature is quite rare for the underlying nets. Topological classification with the TOPOS TTD collection revealed that such a net has never been found in crystals; we have deposited it into the TTD collection under the name sdf1. Further analysis showed that there are four kinds of 12-rings in this 3D framework (Figure S4 in the ). Each ring consists of six Cu2-SBUs that are connected by six halves of organic ligands.
elements.clean_text: To perform topological analysis of the 3D architecture, we have used the TOPOS program package. Topologically, by regarding each Cu2-SBU as a 4-coordinated node (Figure ) and each L as a 3-coordinated node (Figure ), the overall 3D net can be rationalized as a binodal 3,4-coordinated edge-transitive (with one kind of edge) underlying net (i.e., the net of centroids of structural groups) with the point symbol of (123)4(126)3 (Figure ). It is striking that this net has collisions; i.e., some of its vertices have coordinates that are the average of the coordinates of their neighbors. This feature is quite rare for the underlying nets. Topological classification with the TOPOS TTD collection revealed that such a net has never been found in crystals; we have deposited it into the TTD collection under the name sdf1. Further analysis showed that there are four kinds of 12-rings in this 3D framework (Figure S4 in the ). Each ring consists of six Cu2-SBUs that are connected by six halves of organic ligands.

elements.content: Schematic representation of the 3D framework of SDU-9, where the purple balls are the simplified paddlewheel units.
elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic representation of the 3D framework of SDU-9, where the purple balls are the simplified paddlewheel units.

elements.content: The most fascinating and peculiar structural feature of SDU-9 is that all of the rings are catenated together, coming to a complete framework. Because the underlying net is edge-transitive (all edges are equivalent by symmetry), it cannot be naturally split into separate interpenetrating 2D or 3D nets; after breaking any edge, one obtains an unconnected structure. Hence, we call such self-catenation “strong”. The self-catenation is extremely tight: each 12-ring is crossed by more than 100 other 12-rings. Figure demonstrates the unprecedented complexity of self-catenation: all depicted nodes of the underlying net belong to the 176 12-rings that catenate the same (blue) 12-ring. Besides simple (Hopf-type) links between 12-rings, there are a few multilinks (also known as Solomon links) that are rare in self-catenated coordination networks (Figure ). This tight self-catenation causes a high topological density of the net, TD10 = 3245; according to the RCSR database, to the best of our knowledge, this is the highest topological density among all known 3,4-coordinated nets.
elements.clean_text: The most fascinating and peculiar structural feature of SDU-9 is that all of the rings are catenated together, coming to a complete framework. Because the underlying net is edge-transitive (all edges are equivalent by symmetry), it cannot be naturally split into separate interpenetrating 2D or 3D nets; after breaking any edge, one obtains an unconnected structure. Hence, we call such self-catenation "strong". The self-catenation is extremely tight: each 12-ring is crossed by more than 100 other 12-rings. Figure  demonstrates the unprecedented complexity of self-catenation: all depicted nodes of the underlying net belong to the 176 12-rings that catenate the same (blue) 12-ring. Besides simple (Hopf-type) links between 12-rings, there are a few multilinks (also known as Solomon links) that are rare in self-catenated coordination networks (Figure ). This tight self-catenation causes a high topological density of the net, TD10 = 3245; according to the RCSR database, to the best of our knowledge, this is the highest topological density among all known 3,4-coordinated nets.

elements.content: (left) One of the 12-rings (12b, in blue) catenated by 176 other 12-rings in the underlying net sdf1 of SDU-9. (right) One of the 174 simple links between the 12-rings and one of two multilinks.
elements.clean_text: 3  (left) One of the 12-rings (12b, in blue) catenated by 176 other 12-rings in the underlying net sdf1 of SDU-9. (right) One of the 174 simple links between the 12-rings and one of two multilinks.

elements.content: On the basis of the calculation from the PLATON/VOID routine, the total solvent-accessible volume for the desolvated framework after removal of guest solvents and coordinated water molecules is estimated to be 35.9%. To check the permanent porosities of SDU-9, the freshly prepared samples were soaked in methanol and dichloromethane to exchange the less volatile solvent molecules. A color change from bright-blue to blue-green, indicating that open CuII sites similar to those observed for other frameworks have been generated. As shown in Figure , desolvated crystal SDU-9 displays a typical type IV adsorption isotherm. This may derive from the flexibility of the self-catenated net, which causes dislocation moves of the framework upon an increase of the pressure, as found in other soft porous MOFs. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of SDU-9 is 332.8 m2 g–1 calculated from these data.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the calculation from the PLATON/VOID routine, the total solvent-accessible volume for the desolvated framework after removal of guest solvents and coordinated water molecules is estimated to be 35.9%. To check the permanent porosities of SDU-9, the freshly prepared samples were soaked in methanol and dichloromethane to exchange the less volatile solvent molecules. A color change from bright-blue to blue-green, indicating that open CuII sites similar to those observed for other frameworks have been generated. As shown in Figure , desolvated crystal SDU-9 displays a typical type IV adsorption isotherm. This may derive from the flexibility of the self-catenated net, which causes dislocation moves of the framework upon an increase of the pressure, as found in other soft porous MOFs. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area of SDU-9 is 332.8 m2 g-1 calculated from these data.

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (solid circles, adsorption; open circles, desorption).
elements.clean_text: 4  N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K (solid circles, adsorption; open circles, desorption).

elements.content: In summary, a 3D (123)4(126)3 coordination network with high topological density and extremely tight self-catenation of 12-rings has been obtained based on [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs and a tripodal carboxylate linker. The self-catenation is “strong”; i.e., the network cannot be transformed into an array of interpenetrating nets by breaking any chemical bond.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a 3D (123)4(126)3 coordination network with high topological density and extremely tight self-catenation of 12-rings has been obtained based on [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs and a tripodal carboxylate linker. The self-catenation is "strong"; i.e., the network cannot be transformed into an array of interpenetrating nets by breaking any chemical bond.

cln_elements.content: On the basis of the calculation from the PLATON/VOID routine, the total solvent-accessible volume for the desolvated framework after removal of guest solvents and coordinated water molecules is estimated to be 35.9%. To check the permanent porosities of SDU-9, the freshly prepared samples were soaked in methanol and dichloromethane to exchange the less volatile solvent molecules. A color change from bright-blue to blue-green, indicating that open CuII sites similar to those observed for other frameworks have been generated. As shown in Figure , desolvated crystal SDU-9 displays a typical type IV adsorption isotherm. This may derive from the flexibility of the self-catenated net, which causes dislocation moves of the framework upon an increase of the pressure, as found in other soft porous MOFs. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of SDU-9 is 332.8 m2 g–1 calculated from these data.

metadata.title:
A “Strongly”
Self-Catenated Metal–Organic Framework with the Highest Topological
Density among 3,4-Coordinated Nets
